elements.content: The syntheses, structures, and characterization of three series of one-dimensional (1D) and three-dimensional (3D) 3d–4f cluster-based polymers with AA (HGly or HAla) and formate as mixed ligands are described. Under the pH values of 6.0 and 5.2, respectively, three 1D undulating chains [Ln = Gd, (1); Tb, (2); and Dy(3)] and two 3D frameworks [Ln = Gd, (4) and Tb, (5)] with a 3-connected pcu-h network were obtained. Both of them use Gly-based heptanuclear trigonal prism [LnCu6] clusters and mononuclear Ln3+ as nodes linked by syn–anti formate ligands. Moreover, three 3D polymers [Ln = Gd, (6); Tb, (7); and Dy (8)] with a 6-connected pcu network were built from Ala-based [Ln6Cu24] clusters and formate bridges. The formate ligand played an important role not only for the construction of the cluster units but also for their further linkage to extended arrays. Magnetic analyses indicate the three Gd3+-containing compounds bear an interesting magnetocaloric effect, and the −ΔSm(T) values are 5.8, 6.0, and 18.8 J kg1– K–1 (ΔH = 5 T) for 1, 4, and 6, respectively.

Both of them use Gly-based heptanuclear trigonal prism [LnCu6] clusters and mononuclear Ln3+ as nodes linked by syn-anti formate ligands. Moreover, three 3D polymers [Ln = Gd, (6); Tb, (7); and Dy (8)] with a 6-connected pcu network were built from Ala-based [Ln6Cu24] clusters and formate bridges. The formate ligand played an important role not only for the construction of the cluster units but also for their further linkage to extended arrays. Magnetic analyses indicate the three Gd3+-containing compounds bear an interesting magnetocaloric effect, and the -ΔSm(T) values are 5.8, 6.0, and 18.8 J kg1- K-1 (ΔH  = 5 T) for 1, 4, and 6, respectively.

elements.content: With amino acid (HGly or HAla) and formate as mixed ligands, one-dimensional (1D) and three-dimensional (3D) networks based on [LnCu6] clusters and 3D networks based on [Ln6Cu24] clusters were prepared. The Gd-containing polymers show interesting MCEs.

elements.content: In recent decades, 3d–4f heterometallic clusters have attracted great interest because of their versatile intriguing architectures and remarkable magnetic properties, such as the slow relaxation of the magnetization and the magnetocaloric effect (MCE), mainly originated from the considerable lanthanide ion anisotropy (such as Tb3+ and Dy3+) and isotropic spins (such as Gd3+, S = 7/2), respectively. The MCE is based on the change of magnetic entropy upon application of a magnetic field and is environmentally friendly. The use of MCE within molecule-based magnets has a potential to replace the expensive and rare helium-3 for refrigeration in the ultra low-temperature region. To achieve a large MCE, high-nuclearity Gd-containing heterometallic complexes are most promising due to the high isotropic spins of the Gd3+ ion and the possible strong magnetic interaction between 3d and Gd3+ ions. Recent studies have mainly focused on the high-spin zero-dimensional (0D) Gd-containing clusters, while reports are still rare about the research on MCE of extended frameworks, although these compounds may combine the interesting magnetic behavior and other versatile properties such as photoluminescence, catalysis, and gas storage into one structure, leading to potential multifunctional material. So far, the dimensionality–MCE correlations are still unclear and the construction of new multidimensional frameworks with significant MCE becomes significant and necessary.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent decades, 3d-4f heterometallic clusters have attracted great interest because of their versatile intriguing architectures and remarkable magnetic properties, such as the slow relaxation of the magnetization and the magnetocaloric effect (MCE), mainly originated from the considerable lanthanide ion anisotropy (such as Tb3+ and Dy3+) and isotropic spins (such as Gd3+, S = 7/2), respectively. The MCE is based on the change of magnetic entropy upon application of a magnetic field and is environmentally friendly. The use of MCE within molecule-based magnets has a potential to replace the expensive and rare helium-3 for refrigeration in the ultra low-temperature region. To achieve a large MCE, high-nuclearity Gd-containing heterometallic complexes are most promising due to the high isotropic spins of the Gd3+ ion and the possible strong magnetic interaction between 3d and Gd3+ ions. Recent studies have mainly focused on the high-spin zero-dimensional (0D) Gd-containing clusters, while reports are still rare about the research on MCE of extended frameworks, although these compounds may combine the interesting magnetic behavior and other versatile properties such as photoluminescence, catalysis, and gas storage into one structure, leading to potential multifunctional material. So far, the dimensionality-MCE correlations are still unclear and the construction of new multidimensional frameworks with significant MCE becomes significant and necessary.

elements.content: For the past few years, one interesting trend of 3d–4f heterometallic materials was the construction of multidimensional frameworks with polynuclearity, especially high-nuclearity heterometallic clusters as building units. In comparison with the frameworks based on single metal ions, the introduction of the clusters brings two obvious merits: increasing the pore sizes of the frameworks due to the use of the large-sized clusters as units and functionalizing the frameworks through incorporating the clusters with various properties. However, up to now most of the 3d–4f frameworks are based on single metal nodes, and only several examples based on 3d–4f clusters have been reported because of the huge synthetic difficulty.
elements.clean_text: For the past few years, one interesting trend of 3d-4f heterometallic materials was the construction of multidimensional frameworks with polynuclearity, especially high-nuclearity heterometallic clusters as building units. In comparison with the frameworks based on single metal ions, the introduction of the clusters brings two obvious merits: increasing the pore sizes of the frameworks due to the use of the large-sized clusters as units and functionalizing the frameworks through incorporating the clusters with various properties. However, up to now most of the 3d-4f frameworks are based on single metal nodes, and only several examples based on 3d-4f clusters have been reported because of the huge synthetic difficulty.

elements.content: To construct such materials with interesting magnetic properties, an available synthetic strategy is selecting one suitable multidentate organic ligand to build the 3d–4f cluster unit and one proper auxiliary ligand to link the units together. Amino acids (AAs) have been demonstrated as outstanding ligands for the construction of 3d–4f heterometallic clusters, such as [Gd2Ni2], [LnM6] (M = Cu, Ni, and Co), and [Ln6Cu24]. Moreover, several two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with AA-based [Ln6Cu24] clusters as nodes also have been obtained successfully. Formate is the smallest carboxylate and displays multitudinous bridging modes such as syn–syn, syn–anti, and syn–syn/anti, which can mediate ferro- or antiferromagnetic coupling between metal ions in different situations. It has been used to prepare a large number of topologically different 3d or 4f frameworks. Some discrete 3d–4f clusters with fascinating magnetic behaviors also have been obtained with formate as an auxiliary ligand. Furthermore, our previous work has shown that the formate ligand could be used not only to build 3d–4f clusters but also to link them into a one-dimensional (1D) structure. Considering the above, we used AA [AA = glycine (HGly) or alanine (HAla)] and formate (FA) as mixed ligands and have obtained three series of infinite architectures with [LnCu6] or [Ln6Cu24] as building units: 1D undulating chains [Ln2Cu6(Gly)6(FA)3(μ3-OH)3(μ3-OH2)3(H2O)8](ClO4)6·xH2O [Ln = Gd, x = 10, (1); Ln = Tb, x = 15, (2); Ln = Dy, x = 15, (3)], 3D 3-connected pcu-h networks [Ln2Cu6(Gly)6(FA)3(μ3-OH)3(μ3-OH2)3(H2O)9](ClO4)6·xH2O [Ln = Gd, x = 15, (4); Ln = Tb, x = 13, (5)], and 3D 6-connected pcu networks [Ln6Cu24(Ala)12(FA)8(μ3-OH)30(μ2-OH)6(H2O)18](ClO4)10·64H2O [Ln = Gd (6); Tb, (7); Ln = Dy (8)]. Here, their syntheses, structures, and magnetic properties are discussed.

elements.content: The spontaneous aggregation of building blocks in solution that recognize each other through multiple molecular recognition sites (or active sites) has been proven to be an effective way to construct cluster-based frameworks. Previous work about [LnM6] (MCu, Ni, and Co) clusters based on AA ligands showed that all the clusters had similar Ln-centered trigonal prism geometries and could be treated as either the edge ligand (μ2-H2O) or the terminal ligand (μ1-H2O)-substituted products of an unstable intermediate [LnM6(AA)6(μ3-OH)3(μ2-H2O)3(H2O)6]6+, which also bears trigonal prism geometry. The fact that the terminal active sites are active enough to be substituted by other monodentate ligands, such as imidazole or pyridine, inspires us to study the possibility of similar reactions but using a suitable multidentate ligand with the aim of either using the ligands as linkers to connect the heptanuclear trigonal prism [LnM6] clusters into cluster-based extensive structures directly or using part of the donor atoms of the ligand to substitute the terminal active sites of the [LnM6] clusters and the rest to connect with other metal ions or clusters. Our experiment results indicated that the ideas could be achieved by using formate as a bidentate ligand. As shown in Scheme , by controlling the pH value to 6.0 or 5.2, part of the terminal water ligands of the [LnCu6(Gly)6(μ3-OH)3(μ2-H2O)3(H2O)6]6+ species can be substituted to form two different formate-substituted intermediates, which can further assemble with Ln3+ ions to provide either 1D undulating (1, 2, and 3) or 3D 3-connected (4 and 5) architectures, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

The spontaneous aggregation of building blocks in solution that recognize each other through multiple molecular recognition sites (or active sites) has been proven to be an effective way to construct cluster-based frameworks. Previous work about [LnM6] (MCu, Ni, and Co) clusters based on AA ligands showed that all the clusters had similar Ln-centered trigonal prism geometries and could be treated as either the edge ligand (μ2-H2O) or the terminal ligand (μ1-H2O)-substituted products of an unstable intermediate [LnM6(AA)6(μ3-OH)3(μ2-H2O)3(H2O)6]6+, which also bears trigonal prism geometry. The fact that the terminal active sites are active enough to be substituted by other monodentate ligands, such as imidazole or pyridine, inspires us to study the possibility of similar reactions but using a suitable multidentate ligand with the aim of either using the ligands as linkers to connect the heptanuclear trigonal prism [LnM6] clusters into cluster-based extensive structures directly or using part of the donor atoms of the ligand to substitute the terminal active sites of the [LnM6] clusters and the rest to connect with other metal ions or clusters. Our experiment results indicated that the ideas could be achieved by using formate as a bidentate ligand. As shown in Scheme , by controlling the pH value to 6.0 or 5.2, part of the terminal water ligands of the [LnCu6(Gly)6(μ3-OH)3(μ2-H2O)3(H2O)6]6+ species can be substituted to form two different formate-substituted intermediates, which can further assemble with Ln3+ ions to provide either 1D undulating (1, 2, and 3) or 3D 3-connected (4 and 5) architectures, respectively.

elements.content: The reaction is not only susceptive to the pH value but also affected by AA ligands. When HGly was replaced by an HAla ligand, compounds 6–8 based on [Ln6Cu24] units were obtained. The [Ln6Cu24] cluster also has up to 12 active sites (the apical positions of the 12 outer Cu2+ ions of the cluster), which could be substituted by trans-Cu(AA)2 linkers to form multidimensional frameworks. Here, we show that formate ligands could be used to substitute the terminal water molecules at active sites, and new 3D structures (6–8) are achieved.

elements.content: Compounds 1–3 are isomorphous, so only the structure of 1 is discussed in detail. Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group and has a 1D undulating structure based on the syn–anti formate linker, mononuclear Gd3+ and [GdCu6] nodes (Figure a). As shown in Figure b, the [GdCu6] unit can be described as a distorted trigonal prism with six Cu2+ ions located in the vertexes and a Gd3+ ion in the center. The base faces of the trigonal prism are two equilateral triangles with the Cu···Cu edge of ∼5.4 Å. The side edge Cu2···Cu6 chelated by a syn–syn formate is 3.1 Å, shorter than the other two side edges (3.3 Å). The Gd···Cu separation is 3.5 Å. All these data are comparable to those reported for the [LnCu6], [LnNi6], or [LnCo6] trigonal prism clusters.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 1-3 

Compounds 1-3 are isomorphous, so only the structure of 1 is discussed in detail. Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group and has a 1D undulating structure based on the syn-anti formate linker, mononuclear Gd3+ and [GdCu6] nodes (Figure a). As shown in Figure b, the [GdCu6] unit can be described as a distorted trigonal prism with six Cu2+ ions located in the vertexes and a Gd3+ ion in the center. The base faces of the trigonal prism are two equilateral triangles with the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu edge of ~5.4 Å. The side edge Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu6 chelated by a syn-syn formate is 3.1 Å, shorter than the other two side edges (3.3 Å). The Gd⋅⋅⋅Cu separation is 3.5 Å. All these data are comparable to those reported for the [LnCu6], [LnNi6], or [LnCo6] trigonal prism clusters.

elements.content: The μ3-η2:η1:η1 coordination mode is used for six deprotonated Gly ligands, each of which connects two Cu2+ ions of the base edge and the Gd3+ center with the ∠Gd–O–Cu in the range of 101.353(9)–103.604(10)°. Each [Cu2] pair of the side edge is linked by one μ2-OH2 ligand and further bound with the center Gd3+ ion by one μ3-OH– group with the ∠Cu–O(μ2-OH2)-Cu, ∠Cu–O(OH)-Cu, and ∠Gd–O(OH)-Cu in the ranges of 72.868(5)–80.611(6), 106.042(8)–115.266(8), and 104.052(10)–106.919(10)°, respectively. Each Cu2+ ion is six-coordinated and has a distorted octahedral {NO5} donor set with the Cu–O and Cu–N bond lengths falling in the range of 1.918(5)–2.373(6) and 1.937(7)–1.981(8) Å, respectively. The coordination geometry of the nonacoordinate central Gd3+ ion can be described as a monocapped square antiprism, featuring coordination by six oxygen atoms from six Gly ligands and three μ3-OH– groups with the Gd–O distances in the range of 2.403(5)–2.479(5) Å. In contrast, the mononuclear Gd3+ node displays a different coordination environment and has a {O8} square antiprismatic configuration, formed by two formate oxygen atoms and six terminal water molecules with the Gd–O lengths in the range of 2.321(6)–2.433(8) Å.

elements.content: The three formates adopt two coordination modes in 1 (Scheme ). The syn–syn one bridges two Cu2+ ions of one side edge of the trigonal prism (Figure c). Each of the other two bridges one Cu2+ ion from the upper or bottom base face and the mononuclear Gd3+ ion using a syn–anti mode. The mononuclear Gd3+ and [GdCu6] units are connected alternately by the syn–anti formate linkers to form a 1D undulating chain running along the [11̅0] direction. The average Gd···Gd distance and the Gd···Gd···Gd angle in the chain are 8.3 Å and 135.793(3)°, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The three formates adopt two coordination modes in 1 (Scheme ). The syn-syn one bridges two Cu2+ ions of one side edge of the trigonal prism (Figure c). Each of the other two bridges one Cu2+ ion from the upper or bottom base face and the mononuclear Gd3+ ion using a syn-anti mode. The mononuclear Gd3+ and [GdCu6] units are connected alternately by the syn-anti formate linkers to form a 1D undulating chain running along the [11̅0] direction. The average Gd⋅⋅⋅Gd distance and the Gd⋅⋅⋅Gd⋅⋅⋅Gd angle in the chain are 8.3 Å and 135.793(3)°, respectively.

elements.content: Compounds 4 and 5 are isomorphous and only the structure of 4 is discussed in detail. Compound 4 crystallizes in the rhombohedral R3̅ space group and possesses a 3D cationic network built from the syn–anti formate linker, 3-connected Gd3+, and [GdCu6] nodes. The [GdCu6] unit in 4 has a similar structure to that in 1 except (i) the positions of the syn–syn formate that coordinate to two Cu2+ ions (Cu2 and Cu6) of one side edge in 1 is substituted by one terminal water and one syn–anti formate ligand, (ii) the [GdCu6] unit displays a regular trigonal prism geometry with the side edge of ∼3.2 Å and base edge of ∼5.3 Å. The mononuclear Gd3+ node exhibits different coordination geometry from that of 1. It possesses a monocapped square antiprismal {O9} donor set, completed by three formate oxygen atoms and six terminal water molecules with the Gd–O lengths in the range of 2.314(7)–2.524(8) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 4 and 5 

Compounds 4 and 5 are isomorphous and only the structure of 4 is discussed in detail. Compound 4 crystallizes in the rhombohedral R3̅ space group and possesses a 3D cationic network built from the syn-anti formate linker, 3-connected Gd3+, and [GdCu6] nodes. The [GdCu6] unit in 4 has a similar structure to that in 1 except (i) the positions of the syn-syn formate that coordinate to two Cu2+ ions (Cu2 and Cu6) of one side edge in 1 is substituted by one terminal water and one syn-anti formate ligand, (ii) the [GdCu6] unit displays a regular trigonal prism geometry with the side edge of ~3.2 Å and base edge of ~5.3 Å. The mononuclear Gd3+ node exhibits different coordination geometry from that of 1. It possesses a monocapped square antiprismal {O9} donor set, completed by three formate oxygen atoms and six terminal water molecules with the Gd-O lengths in the range of 2.314(7)-2.524(8) Å.

elements.content: The Gly ligands in 4 adopt the same μ3-η2:η1:η1 coordination mode as that in 1. The three formate ligands all use the syn–anti bridging mode and point at three different directions, each of which connects one Cu2+ ion [from the upper base face (Cu1) or the bottom base face (Cu5 and Cu6)] of the [GdCu6] unit and the mononuclear Gd3+ node with the Gd···Gd···Gd angles in the range of 89.153(4)–134.036(4)°. The 3-connected Gd3+ and [GdCu6] nodes are connected alternately by the syn–anti formate linkers to form a 3D cationic framework which has hexagonal channels with two different interior environments viewed along the c axis, as shown in Figure (panels c and d). Disordered ClO4 – anions and H2O solvent molecules are encapsulated in these channels. To get further insight into the nature of 4, a topological analysis of this 3D framework was performed with the TOPOS program, which reveals that the framework is a 3-connected pcu-h network with a Schäfli symbol of (6 × 102) (Figure ).

elements.content: Compounds 6–8 are also isomorphous. Compound 6 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group and has a 3D cationic framework derived from formate linkers and the [Gd6Cu24] node. The [Gd6Cu24] cluster unit consists of the [Gd6Cu12] octhedral inner core and six outer [Cu2] units. The inner [Gd6Cu12] core can be well-described as an octahedron with pseudocubic O h symmetry. Six Gd3+ ions are located at the vertices of the octahedron, and twelve Cu2+ ions lie in the midpoints of the octahedral edges. The average distances of Gd···Gd, Gd···Cu (inner), and Cu (inner)···Cu (inner) are 7.0, 3.5, and 3.4 Å, respectively, in agreement with those reported for the compounds bearing the [Ln6Cu12] motif. Each face of the octahedron includes three Gd3+ ions and three Cu2+ ions, where every GdCu2 unit is capped by one μ3-OH– group. The angles of Cu–O–Cu and Gd–O–Cu fall in the range of 114.3(2)–122.7(2) and 101.6(2)–106.2(2)°, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 6-8 

Compounds 6-8 are also isomorphous. Compound 6 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group and has a 3D cationic framework derived from formate linkers and the [Gd6Cu24] node. The [Gd6Cu24] cluster unit consists of the [Gd6Cu12] octhedral inner core and six outer [Cu2] units. The inner [Gd6Cu12] core can be well-described as an octahedron with pseudocubic O  h  symmetry. Six Gd3+ ions are located at the vertices of the octahedron, and twelve Cu2+ ions lie in the midpoints of the octahedral edges. The average distances of Gd⋅⋅⋅Gd, Gd⋅⋅⋅Cu (inner), and Cu (inner)⋅⋅⋅Cu (inner) are 7.0, 3.5, and 3.4 Å, respectively, in agreement with those reported for the compounds bearing the [Ln6Cu12] motif. Each face of the octahedron includes three Gd3+ ions and three Cu2+ ions, where every GdCu2 unit is capped by one μ3-OH- group. The angles of Cu-O-Cu and Gd-O-Cu fall in the range of 114.3(2)-122.7(2) and 101.6(2)-106.2(2)°, respectively.

elements.content: For each outer [Cu2] unit, two Cu2+ ions are bundled together with one Gd3+ ion by one μ3-OH– group and two μ3-η2:η1:η1 Ala ligands, which use a NO donor set to chelate one outer Cu2+ ion and also employ its two oxygen atoms to coordinate to one inner Cu2+ ion and the Gd3+ ion, respectively. The two outer Cu2+ ions are further bound by one μ2-OH2 ligand and one syn–syn (or syn–syn/anti) formate with ∠Cu–O(μ2-OH2)-Cu in the range of 70.363(2)–74.824(2)°. The average Gd···Cu (outer) distance is about 3.5 Å, while the neighboring Cu (outer)···Cu (outer) distance is 3.0 Å, shorter than that of the Cu (inner)···Cu (inner). The ∠Gd–O(OH)-Cu, ∠Gd–O(carboxylate)-Cu, and ∠Cu–O(OH)-Cu are in the ranges of 106.4(2)–107.4(2), 103.383(2)–104.484(2), and 99.9(2)–102.9(2)°, respectively. Each Gd3+ ion is nine-coordinated and exhibits a monocapped square antiprism, featuring coordination by five μ3-OH– groups, two terminal H2O ligands, and two oxygen atoms from two Ala ligands. The coordination geometry of the pentacoordinate inner Cu2+ ion can be described as a square pyramid, completed by one oxygen atom from one Ala ligand and four μ3-OH– groups. For every outer [Cu2] unit, the two Cu2+ ions both have an octahedral NO5 donor set. One Cu2+ ion is chelated by one N,O-donor Ala ligand and further coordinated by one syn–syn formate oxygen atom, one μ3-OH– group, one μ2-OH2 ligand, and one terminal water ligand. The other has the same coordination environment except that the terminal water ligand was replaced by one oxygen atom from one syn–anti formate linker or from one syn–syn/anti formate ligand of the neighboring [Gd6Cu24] unit. Selected bond lengths and angles of 6 are listed in Table S5 of the .

elements.content: There are four kinds of bridging modes for the formate ligands in 6. (I) Four formate ligands adopt a syn–syn mode, and each one connects two neighboring outer Cu2+ ions from one [Gd6Cu24] unit. (II) Each of two syn–syn/anti formates first bridges two outer Cu2+ ions from one [Gd6Cu24] unit just like the syn–syn formate ligand and further links one outer Cu2+ ion from another [Gd6Cu24] unit with the help of one its oxygen atoms. (III) The syn–syn(syn) formate ligand coordinates two outer Cu2+ ions from two neighboring [Gd6Cu24] units, and the two Cu2+ ions are located at the same side of not only the line through the two formate oxygen atoms but also the plane defined by three atoms of the formate. (IV) The two Cu2+ ions bridged by the syn–syn(anti) formate ligand are also from two neighboring [Gd6Cu24] units and located at the same side of the line defined by two formate oxygen atoms; however, they are situated at two different sides of the formate plane. Compared to the common syn–syn and syn–anti bridging modes, the syn–syn(syn) and syn–syn(anti) formate ligands have not been reported as we know, which may play an important role in the formation of the 3D framework.

(III) The syn-syn(syn) formate ligand coordinates two outer Cu2+ ions from two neighboring [Gd6Cu24] units, and the two Cu2+ ions are located at the same side of not only the line through the two formate oxygen atoms but also the plane defined by three atoms of the formate. (IV) The two Cu2+ ions bridged by the syn-syn(anti) formate ligand are also from two neighboring [Gd6Cu24] units and located at the same side of the line defined by two formate oxygen atoms; however, they are situated at two different sides of the formate plane. Compared to the common syn-syn and syn-anti bridging modes, the syn-syn(syn) and syn-syn(anti) formate ligands have not been reported as we know, which may play an important role in the formation of the 3D framework.

elements.content: Each [Gd6Cu24] unit is connected to six others through two syn–syn/anti formate oxygens, two syn–syn(syn) and two syn–syn(anti) formate linkers (Figure b). First, each [Gd6Cu24] unit connects to two others through two syn–syn/anti formate oxygens, which bridge two outer Cu2+ ions from the two neighboring [Gd6Cu24] units, respectively, with the Cu(outer)···Cu(outher) distance of 3.756 (1) Å. Second, the [Gd6Cu24] unit connects to another two [Gd6Cu24] units through two syn–syn(syn) formate linkers, which span a Cu(outer)···Cu(outher) distance of 5.389 (1) Å. Lastly, the [Gd6Cu24] unit further connects to two others through two syn–syn(anti) formate linkers, which bridge a Cu(outer)···Cu(outher) distance of 4.998 (1) Å. The resulting 3D framework bears two types of rhomboid channels (dimensions of about 16.5 × 6.1 and 11.5 × 5.3 Å, calculated between opposite copper atoms) viewed along the b axis, as shown in Figure c. Disordered ClO4 – anions and H2O solvent molecules are encapsulated in these channels. If treating the [Gd6Cu24] units as individual nodes, this network can be considered as a 6-connected pcu topology with a Schäfli symbol of (412·63), as analysized using TOPOS (Figure d).

If treating the [Gd6Cu24] units as individual nodes, this network can be considered as a 6-connected pcu topology with a Schäfli symbol of (412⋅63), as analysized using TOPOS (Figure d).

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibilities of 1–8 have been studied in the temperature range of 2–300 K with an applied direct current (dc) magnetic field of 1000 Oe. At room temperature, the χM T values of 1–4 are in agreement with the expected values: observed 18.68 cm3 mol–1 K for 1 and 18.21 cm3 mol–1 K for 4 [calcd 18.00 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Gd3+ (S = 7/2, g = 2) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions], observed 26.22 cm3 mol–1 K for 2 [calcd 25.88 cm3 mol–1 K for two Tb3+ (S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions], observed 30.16 cm3 mol–1 K for 3 [calcd 30.58 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ (S = 5/2, L = 5, g = 4/3) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions]. For 5, the χM T value is 29.19 cm3 mol–1 K, larger than the expected value of 25.88 cm3 mol–1 K for two spin-only S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2 and six S = 1/2, g = 2 metal centers.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities of 1-8 have been studied in the temperature range of 2-300 K with an applied direct current (dc) magnetic field of 1000 Oe. At room temperature, the χM T values of 1-4 are in agreement with the expected values: observed 18.68 cm3 mol-1 K for 1 and 18.21 cm3 mol-1 K for 4 [calcd 18.00 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled Gd3+ (S = 7/2, g = 2) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions], observed 26.22 cm3 mol-1 K for 2 [calcd 25.88 cm3 mol-1 K for two Tb3+ (S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions], observed 30.16 cm3 mol-1 K for 3 [calcd 30.58 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ (S = 5/2, L = 5, g = 4/3) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions]. For 5, the χM T value is 29.19 cm3 mol-1 K, larger than the expected value of 25.88 cm3 mol-1 K for two spin-only S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2 and six S = 1/2, g = 2 metal centers.

elements.content: Plots of χM T vs T for 1–5 under a 1000 Oe dc field between 2 and 300 K.
elements.clean_text: 5  Plots of χM T vs T for 1-5 under a 1000 Oe dc field between 2 and 300 K.

elements.content: Upon cooling, for 1, the χM T value increases gradually to 19.43 cm3 mol–1 K at 50 K and then increases rapidly to 21.99 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K, which indicates a dominant ferromagnetic interaction between the metal centers. For 2 and 5, the χM T products remain almost constant before 40 K and then decrease abruptly to 19.02 and 14.18 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. For 3, χM T decreases significantly to 23.18 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The continuing fall of the χM T values may be ascribed to a combination of the crystal-field effect of lanthanum ions (Tb3+ for 2 and 5; Dy3+ for 3) and the antiferromagnetic interactions between the metal centers. For 4, the χM T value decreases gradually to 17.03 cm3 mol–1 K at 30 K before decreasing quickly to 15.41 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K, which may be due to the zero-field splitting of the ground states and/or the antiferromagnetic interactions between the metal centers.

For 4, the χM T value decreases gradually to 17.03 cm3 mol-1 K at 30 K before decreasing quickly to 15.41 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K, which may be due to the zero-field splitting of the ground states and/or the antiferromagnetic interactions between the metal centers.

elements.content: For 6, 7, and 8, the χM T values at 300 K are 56.75, 80.81, and 94.66 cm3 mol–1 K, respectively, close to the expected values: 56.25 cm3 mol–1 K for 6 with six isolated S = 7/2 and twenty-four S = 1/2, g = 2 metal centers; 79.17 cm3 mol–1 K for 7 with six S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2, and twenty-four S = 1/2, g = 2 centers; and 94.02 cm3 mol–1 K for 8 with six S = 5/2, L = 5, g = 4/3, and twenty-four S = 1/2, g = 2 centers. With lowering the temperature, for 6, the χM T value decreases sizeably to 50.68 cm3 mol–1 K at 80 K before increasing rapidly to a maximum of 58.99 cm3 mol–1 K at 6 K and then decreasing abruptly to 52.87 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. This magnetic behavior is similar to that reported for a 3D framework based on the [Gd6Cu24Na12] unit but different from other [Gd6Cu24] cluster complexes. The first decrease of the χM T value indicates the presence of the antiferromagnetic interactions between the metal centers, while the subsequent increase demonstrates that the overall magnetic exchange interaction is still ferromagnetic, which results in the ferrimagnetic behavior of this 3D cluster compound. The decrease in the low-temperature region may be attributed to the antiferromagnetic coupling between the clusters and the zero-field splitting of the ground states. For 7, the χM T value increases gradually to 84.76 cm3 mol–1 K at 34 K and then increases quickly to a maximum of 94.09 cm3 mol–1 K at 5 K, which suggests the dominant ferromagnetic interaction between the metal ions. With further cooling, the χM T value decreases sharply to 90.50 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K, which may be associated with the intercluster antiferromagnetic interactions and the crystal-field effects. For 8, the χM T value remains nearly constant between 300 and 100 K and then decreases to a minimum of 90.41 cm3 mol–1 K at 23 K before increasing to 95.83 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The crystal-field effects may be responsible for the decrease, while the increase indicates the presence of the ferromagnetic interactions between the ions.

elements.content: The plots of the field dependence of the magnetization at low temperature (Figures S9a, S10a, and 7a of the ) show that the magnetization values for 1, 4, and 6 increase steadily and reach 17.6, 16.3, and 55.7 NμB at 2 K and 5 T, respectively, without saturation, indicating the presence of the low-lying excited states. For 7, the magnetization value at 1.8 K and 5 T is 42.9 NμB, lower than the excepted value of 78.0 NμB for six spin-only S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2, and twenty-four S = 1/2 and g = 2 ions, which suggests the presence of crystal field effects, leading to a ground state not having a higher M value and low-lying excited states.

For 7, the magnetization value at 1.8 K and 5 T is 42.9 NμB, lower than the excepted value of 78.0 NμB for six spin-only S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2, and twenty-four S = 1/2 and g = 2 ions, which suggests the presence of crystal field effects, leading to a ground state not having a higher M value and low-lying excited states.

elements.content: For 6, the presence of Gd3+ ions and the large magnetization value are advantageous for a large MCE, and the magnetic entropy change −Δ S m was calculated from the M(H,T) data based on the Maxwell relation: Δ S m(T) = ∫[∂M – (T,H)/∂T] H dH. As shown in Figure b, the peak value is 18.8 J kg1– K–1 at 2 K for a field change of 0–5 T, smaller than the maximum entropy value of 34.7 J kg1– K–1 per mole, calculated for the sum of the individual contributions from the Cu2+ and Gd3+ spins using the equation −Δ S m = ∑R ln(2S + 1), which may be due to the antiferromagnetic interactions between neighboring clusters. This value is smaller than the maximum of 50.1 J kg–1 K–1 for the 3D Mn2+–Gd3+ framework; however, it is comparable to those observed for other Cu–Gd cluster compounds reported recently. Furthermore, the magnetic entropy change for 1 and 4 were also studied by the same method (Figures S9b and S10b of the ). The maximum values for 1 and 4 at 2 K for a field change of 0–5 T are 5.8 and 6.0 J kg1– K–1, respectively, which are both obviously smaller than the calculated maximum of 30.1 and 28.7 J kg1– K–1. Interestingly, 1 and 4 are 1D and 3D polymeric compounds based on similar cluster units but show almost the same MCE values. Currently, a large metal/ligand mass ratio is proposed to be very important for a Gd-containing molecule exhibiting a large MCE. Winpenny et al. even presumed that the MCE value may be proportional to the density of the gadolinium. However, here, although 1 and 4 have similar densities of the gadolinium with 6, their observed MCE maximum values are both much smaller than that of 6. This may be because 6 is based on a higher cluster unit and has a larger magnetization value than 1 and 4 at a low temperature and high field.

elements.content: The dynamics of the magnetization for 1–8 were investigated in an ac field with a zero dc field. No frequency dependence or an obvious imaginary component (χ″) of the susceptibility has been observed except for 7, which indicates that the zero field relaxation is faster than the employed frequencies, even at the lowest investigated temperature (1.8 K). For 7, the ac measurements show that the χ″ signals increase upon cooling below 2.8 K (Figure S10b of the ), while no peak is observed above 1.8 K, suggesting that a long-range ferromagnetic ordering may occur below 1.8 K. To unambiguously confirm whether this is a magnetic ordering or a relaxation due to the presence of the Tb3+ ion, further study through single crystal micro-SQUID measurements would be required. At present, we do not have this facility at our disposal.

elements.content: In summary, eight new heterometallic 1D or 3D cluster-based polymers with formate as the bridging ligand have been synthesized successfully through a self-assembly reaction. With Gly as a ligand, either a 1D undulating chain (1–3) or 3D 3-connected pcu-h architectures (4 and 5) based on [LnCu6] units were obtained under different pH values. With Ala as a ligand, 6-connected pcu networks (6–8) based on [Ln6Cu24] units were prepared. The Gd-containing compounds show interesting magnetocaloric properties. Further investigation of the construction of other polymeric compounds based on the 3d–4f clusters is being pursued.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, eight new heterometallic 1D or 3D cluster-based polymers with formate as the bridging ligand have been synthesized successfully through a self-assembly reaction. With Gly as a ligand, either a 1D undulating chain (1-3) or 3D 3-connected pcu-h architectures (4 and 5) based on [LnCu6] units were obtained under different pH values. With Ala as a ligand, 6-connected pcu networks (6-8) based on [Ln6Cu24] units were prepared. The Gd-containing compounds show interesting magnetocaloric properties. Further investigation of the construction of other polymeric compounds based on the 3d-4f clusters is being pursued.

elements.content: All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Aqueous solutions of lanthanum perchlorate were prepared by digesting lanthanide oxides in concentrated perchloric acid. Elemental analyses were recorded using a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRPD) measurements were determined on a Riguku D/Max-2400 X-ray Diffractometer using Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. FT-IR spectra were carried out in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on a JASCO FT/IR-430 spectrometer with KBr pellets. Magnetic measurements were performed on a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer MPMS XL-7. Dried samples of compounds 1–5 were used in the magnetic measurements, while polycrystalline samples of compounds 6–8 were taken from the mother liquor and fixed speedily into a capsule using eicosane because they are unstable and easily lose their lattice water molecules. The data were corrected for the sample holder and the diamagnetic contributions.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Aqueous solutions of lanthanum perchlorate were prepared by digesting lanthanide oxides in concentrated perchloric acid. Elemental analyses were recorded using a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRPD) measurements were determined on a Riguku D/Max-2400 X-ray Diffractometer using Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. FT-IR spectra were carried out in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a JASCO FT/IR-430 spectrometer with KBr pellets. Magnetic measurements were performed on a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer MPMS XL-7. Dried samples of compounds 1-5 were used in the magnetic measurements, while polycrystalline samples of compounds 6-8 were taken from the mother liquor and fixed speedily into a capsule using eicosane because they are unstable and easily lose their lattice water molecules. The data were corrected for the sample holder and the diamagnetic contributions.

elements.content: To a mixture (10 mL) of 1 M Ln(ClO4)3 (1 mL, 1 mmol) (Ln = Gd, Tb and Dy) aqueous solution, Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (741 mg, 2 mmol), HGly (75 mg, 1 mmol), and sodium formate (136 mg, 2 mmol) were added. The pH value of the resulting solution was carefully adjusted to 6.0 by slow addition of 0.1 M NaOH solution. After 10 min of stirring, the solution was filtrated. elements.content: Data of 1–8 were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD area detector system with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Ǻ) radiation. Thereinto, the crystals of 6–8 were mounted onto fine glass fibers, using viscous hydrocarbon oil. Data reduction and unit cell refinement were performed with Smart-CCD software. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and were refined by full-matrix least-squares methods using SHELXL-97. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically except two oxygen atoms, O33 of 1 and O3D of 6, and two disordered carbon atoms, C9 of 2 and C30 of 6. The occupy factors are 0.45 (4) and 0.55 (4) for C9A and C9B, 0.53 (3) and 0.47 (3) for C30A and C30B, respectively. Hydrogen atoms on organic ligands were placed in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Hydrogen atoms related to oxygen atoms molecules could not be located. Because the disordered free water molecules and perchlorate anions could not be modeled properly, PLATON/SQUEEZE was used to calculate the solvent disorder area and remove its contribution to the overall intensity data. The total solvent accessible area volume was 899, 895, 897, 788, 789, and 2720 Å3, and the residual electron density amounted to 392, 447, 443, 448, 421, and 1135 e per formula for 1–6, respectively, corresponding roughly to perchlorate anions (6 for 1–5 and 10 for 6) and water molecules (10 for 1, 15 for 2–4, 13 for 5, and 64 for 6). Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for 1–6 are summarized in Table S1 of the . Crystal data of compounds 7 and 8 were also collected. Due to the weak intensities, only preliminary structures can be observed. Both of them are isomorphous with 6, as also confirmed by powder XRD patterns. Their cell parameters are listed in Table S2 of the .

Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction Analysis

Data of 1-8 were collected at 293(2) K on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD area detector system with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Ǻ) radiation. Thereinto, the crystals of 6-8 were mounted onto fine glass fibers, using viscous hydrocarbon oil. Data reduction and unit cell refinement were performed with Smart-CCD software. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and were refined by full-matrix least-squares methods using SHELXL-97. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically except two oxygen atoms, O33 of 1 and O3D of 6, and two disordered carbon atoms, C9 of 2 and C30 of 6. The occupy factors are 0.45 (4) and 0.55 (4) for C9A and C9B, 0.53 (3) and 0.47 (3) for C30A and C30B, respectively. Hydrogen atoms on organic ligands were placed in idealized positions and refined using a riding model. Hydrogen atoms related to oxygen atoms molecules could not be located. Because the disordered free water molecules and perchlorate anions could not be modeled properly, PLATON/SQUEEZE was used to calculate the solvent disorder area and remove its contribution to the overall intensity data. The total solvent accessible area volume was 899, 895, 897, 788, 789, and 2720 Å3, and the residual electron density amounted to 392, 447, 443, 448, 421, and 1135 e per formula for 1-6, respectively, corresponding roughly to perchlorate anions (6 for 1-5 and 10 for 6) and water molecules (10 for 1, 15 for 2-4, 13 for 5, and 64 for 6). Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for 1-6 are summarized in Table S1 of the . Crystal data of compounds 7 and 8 were also collected. Due to the weak intensities, only preliminary structures can be observed. Both of them are isomorphous with 6, as also confirmed by powder XRD patterns. Their cell parameters are listed in Table S2 of the .

cln_elements.content:
The syntheses, structures, and characterization of three series of one-dimensional (1D) and three-dimensional (3D) 3d–4f cluster-based polymers with AA (HGly or HAla) and formate as mixed ligands are described. Under the pH values of 6.0 and 5.2, respectively, three 1D undulating chains [Ln = Gd, (1); Tb, (2); and Dy(3)] and two 3D frameworks [Ln = Gd, (4) and Tb, (5)] with a 3-connected pcu-h network were obtained. Both of them use Gly-based heptanuclear trigonal prism [LnCu6] clusters and mononuclear Ln3+ as nodes linked by syn–anti formate ligands. Moreover, three 3D polymers [Ln = Gd, (6); Tb, (7); and Dy (8)] with a 6-connected pcu network were built from Ala-based [Ln6Cu24] clusters and formate bridges. The formate ligand played an important role not only for the construction of the cluster units but also for their further linkage to extended arrays. Magnetic analyses indicate the three Gd3+-containing compounds bear an interesting magnetocaloric effect, and the −ΔSm(T) values are 5.8, 6.0, and 18.8 J kg1– K–1 (ΔH = 5 T) for 1, 4, and 6, respectively.

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities of 1–8 have been studied in the temperature range of 2–300 K with an applied direct current (dc) magnetic field of 1000 Oe. At room temperature, the χM T values of 1–4 are in agreement with the expected values: observed 18.68 cm3 mol–1 K for 1 and 18.21 cm3 mol–1 K for 4 [calcd 18.00 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Gd3+ (S = 7/2, g = 2) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions], observed 26.22 cm3 mol–1 K for 2 [calcd 25.88 cm3 mol–1 K for two Tb3+ (S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions], observed 30.16 cm3 mol–1 K for 3 [calcd 30.58 cm3 mol–1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ (S = 5/2, L = 5, g = 4/3) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions]. For 5, the χM T value is 29.19 cm3 mol–1 K, larger than the expected value of 25.88 cm3 mol–1 K for two spin-only S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2 and six S = 1/2, g = 2 metal centers.

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities of 1-8 have been studied in the temperature range of 2-300 K with an applied direct current (dc) magnetic field of 1000 Oe. At room temperature, the χM T values of 1-4 are in agreement with the expected values: observed 18.68 cm3 mol-1 K for 1 and 18.21 cm3 mol-1 K for 4 [calcd 18.00 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled Gd3+ (S = 7/2, g = 2) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions], observed 26.22 cm3 mol-1 K for 2 [calcd 25.88 cm3 mol-1 K for two Tb3+ (S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions], observed 30.16 cm3 mol-1 K for 3 [calcd 30.58 cm3 mol-1 K for two uncoupled Dy3+ (S = 5/2, L = 5, g = 4/3) and six Cu2+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions]. For 5, the χM T value is 29.19 cm3 mol-1 K, larger than the expected value of 25.88 cm3 mol-1 K for two spin-only S = 3, L = 3, g = 3/2 and six S = 1/2, g = 2 metal centers.
